Question: How is effective traffic scanning accomplished?
Option A: Smoothly scanning the sky from left to right, as if reading.
Option B: A series of short, regularly spaced eye movements that bring successive areas of the sky into the central visual field.
Option C: Focusing on one spot and allowing peripheral vision to detect movement.
Explanation: Effective scanning is accomplished with a series of short, regularly spaced eye movements that bring successive areas of the sky into the central visual field. Each movement should not exceed 10 degrees, and each should be observed for at least 1 second to enable detection.

Question: Who is responsible for proper preflight planning?
Explanation: The remote pilot in command is responsible for proper planning and the execution of that planning to ensure a safe flight.

Question: The most effective method of scanning for other aircraft for collision avoidance during daylight hours is to use
Option A: regularly spaced concentration on the 3-, 9-, and 12-o'clock positions.
Option B: peripheral vision by scanning small sectors and utilizing offcenter viewing.
Option C: a series of short, regularly spaced eye movements to search each 10-degree sector.
Explanation: The eyes can only focus on a narrow viewing area, so systematically concentrating on sections of the sky for short intervals allows for effective scanning.

Question: Which technique should a pilot use to scan for traffic to the right and left during straight-and-level flight?
Option A: Continuous sweeping of the windshield from right to left.
Option B: Systematically focus on different segments of the sky for short intervals.
Option C: Concentrate on relative movement detected in the peripheral vision area.
Explanation: The eyes can only focus on a narrow viewing area, so systematically concentrating on sections of the sky for short intervals allows for effective scanning.

Question: How can you determine if another aircraft is on a collision course with your aircraft?
Option A: The other aircraft will always appear to get larger and closer at a rapid rate.
Option B: There will be no apparent relative motion between your aircraft and the other aircraft.
Option C: The nose of each aircraft is pointed at the same point in space.
Explanation: If another aircraft has no apparent relative motion, it is likely on a collision course with you.

Question: Invulnerability is defined as a hazardous attitude that can affect the judgement of an RPIC. Invulnerability is:

Question: You plan to operate a 33lb sUAS to capture aerial imagery over real estate for use in sales listings. Is this sUAS operation subject to 14 CFR part 107?

Question: Which of the following sources of information should you consult first when determining what maintenance should be performed on an sUAS or its components?
Explanation: Manufacturers may recommend a maintenance or replacement schedule for the unmanned aircraft and system components based on time-in-service limits and other factors. Follow all manufacturer maintenance recommendations to achieve the longest and safest service life of the sUAS. If the sUAS or component manufacturer does not provide scheduled maintenance instructions, it is recommended that you establish your own scheduled maintenance protocol._

Question: How often is the Remote PIC required to inspect the sUAS to ensure that it is in a condition for safe operation?
Explanation: Before beginning any sUAS flight operation, the remote PIC must assess the operating environment, inform any supporting crewmembers about the operation and their roles, inspect the sUAS to ensure that it is in a condition for safe operation, and maintain documents required in the event of an on-site FAA inspection

Question: During your preflight inspection you determine that your UAS requires some unscheduled maintenance. What should you do?
Option A: Fly the planned mission as possible as UAS systems are inherently safe
Option B: Fly the mission until you notice any annomolies in the flight characteristics of the UAS
Option C: Repair the UAS before continuing the mission
Explanation: Do not conduct flight operations until the discrepancy is corrected based on in accordance with the manufacturerês instructions or, in lieu of that, within known industry best practices.

Question: When must you make your UAS available to the FAA for inspection and testing?
Option A: Prior to having your UAS registered
Option C: The FAA does not need to inspect small comercially produced UAS.
Explanation: You must make available to the FAA, upon request, the sUAS for inspection or testing. 14 CFR 107.7

Question: A professional wildlife photographer operates an sUAS from a moving truck to capture aerial images of migrating birds in remote wetlands. The driver of the truck does not serve any crewmember role in the operation. Is this compliant with Part 107?
Option A: Compliant with part 107 because it is not transporting another person's property for compensation.
Option B: Compliant because it qualifies for a part 107 waiver

Question: Power company employees use an sUAS to inspect a long stretch of high voltage powerlines. Due to muddy conditions, their vehicle must stay beside the road and the crew uses binoculars to maintain visual line of sight with the aircraft.
Option A: Compliant with part 107 in all cases
Option B: Not compliant with part 107 unless only used briefly
Explanation: Visual line of sight must be accomplished and maintained by unaided vision, except vision that is corrected by the use of eyeglasses (spectacles) or contact lenses. Vision aids, such as binoculars, may be used only momentarily to enhance situational awareness. For example, the Remote PIC, person manipulating the controls, or visual observer may use vision aids briefly to avoid flying over persons or to avoid conflicting with other aircraft.

Question: Which of the following individuals may process an application for a part 107 remote pilot certificate with an sUAS rating?
Explanation: An FAA-authorized individual may be a Certified Flight Instructor (CFI), Airman Certification Representative (ACR) for a pilot school, a person designated by a Flight Standards District Office (FSDO), or Designated Pilot Examiner (DPE)

Question: When must the remote PIC inspect the UAS to determine that it is safe for flight?
Option B: After a hard landing or incident
Option C: Onlt when the UAS appears to be operating abnormally
Explanation: The remote PIC must perform checks of the UA prior to each flight to determine if the sUAS is in a condition for safe operation.

Question: What is the maximum groundspeed of a UAS to be operated under part 107
Explanation: Maximum groundspeed of a small UAS is limited to 100 mph (87 knots).

Question: For the purposes of small UAS flights, what time constitutes twilight?
Option A: One hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise
Option B: Thirty minutes after sunset and thirty minutes before sunrise
Option C: The time between sunset and civil evening twilight and the time between morning civil twilight and sunrise
Explanation: Twilight for UAS purposes is 30 minutes before official sunrise to 30 minutes after official sunset, local time.

Question: What equipment is required to operate a small UAS in twilight?
Explanation: You can fly during daylight or in twilight (30 minutes before official sunrise to 30 minutes after official sunset, local time) with appropriate anti-collision lighting.Ê

Question: What is the minimum weather visibility requires to operate a small UAS?
Explanation: Minimum weather visibility is three miles from your control station.

Question: Which of the following UAS flights is illegal?
Option A: Flying over a large group of people in a covered stadium
Option B: Flying directly over people participating in the UAS operation
Explanation: You cannot fly a small UAS over anyone who is not directly participating in the operation, not under a covered structure, or not inside a covered stationary vehicle.Ê

Question: Which of the folllowing operations must be reported to the FAA?
Explanation: A remote PIC must report to the FAA within 10 days of any operation that results in at least serious injury, loss of consciousness, or property damage of at least $500.

Question: How many days does a remote PIC have to notify the FAA of a reportable incident?
Explanation: A remote PIC must report to the FAA within 10 days of any operation that results in at least serious injury, loss of consciousness, or property damage of at least $500.

Question: A small UAS must be operated close enough to the remote PIC that
Option A: the remote PIC can see the UAS unaided by binoculars or other systems
Option B: the UAS remains visual line of sight with the aid of binoculars
Option C: the UAS remains within radio communication range
Explanation: At all times the small unmanned aircraft must remain close enough to the remote pilot in command and the person manipulating the flight controls of the small UAS for those people to be capable of seeing the aircraft with vision unaided by any device other than corrective lenses.

Question: Which crew members must remain in visual line of sight of the small UAS?
Option A: The remote PIC, person manipulating the flight controls, or the visual observer
Option C: The remote PIC and the person manipulating the flight controls
Explanation: The UAS must remain within visual line of sight of the remote PIC and the person manipulating the flight controls of the small UAS. Alternatively, the UAS must remain within VLOS of the visual observer. However, even if you use a visual observer, you must still keep your unmanned aircraft close enough to be able to see it if something unexpected happens.

Question: Which of the following has the right of way over the others?
Option C: A small UAS in an emergency situation
Explanation: A small UAS must yield right of way to other aircraft.

Question: How many small UAS operations may one person operate at one time?
Option B: Only one, unless each operation has a dedicated visual observer
Option C: Only one, unless each operation has a dedcated visual obeserver and person manipulating the flight controls.
Explanation: No person may act as a remote pilot in command or VO for more than one unmanned aircraft operation at one time.

Question: Which of the following operations is legal?
Option A: Operating a small UAS from a moving aircraft
Option B: Operating a small UAS from a moving vehicle over sparsely populated areas
Option C: Operating a small UAS from a moving vehicle over densely populated areas
Explanation: Under part 107, operations are not allowed from a moving aircraft, nor are they allowed over densely populated areas. Furthermore, the remote PIC must not be the person operating the moving vehicle.

Question: How old must a person be to qualify for a remote pilot certificate?
Explanation: To qualify for a remote PIC, a person must be at least 16 years old and must be vetted by the TSA.

Question: Are foreign-certified pilots allowed to conduct UAS operations in the United States?
Option A: Yes, as long as the certification comes from an appropriate government body
Option B: Yes, as long as the person takes training on U.S. specific laws
Option C: No, all UAS operations in the U.S. must have an FAA certified remote PIC overseeing the operation
Explanation: Until international standards are developed, foreign-certificated UAS pilots will be required to obtain an FAA-issued remote pilot certificate with a small UAS rating.

Question: Transportation of property for compensation or hire is allowed under part 107 provided that
Option A: The flight occurs wholly within the bounds of a State and does not involve transport between (1) Hawaii and another place in Hawaii through airspace outside Hawaii; (2) the District of Columbia and another place in the District of Columbia; or (3) a territory or possession of the United States and another place in the same territory or possession.
Option B: The flight does not cross more than one state or territory boundary
Option C: The small UAS operator receives a permit to cary hazardous materials
Explanation: The flight must occur solely within one state and carriage of hazardous materials is not allowed.

Question: Under part 107, a small UAS must be
Option B: certified with the FAA as airworthy
Option C: manufactured by an FAA-certified UAS manufacturer
Explanation: The FAA does not require small UAS to comply with current agency airworthiness standards or obtain aircraft certification, but it must be registered.

Question: A complete preflght inspection may NOT need to include
Option A: Checking the communications link between the UAS and the control station
Option B: Checking the safety-pertinent systems, including the command and control systems, are functioning properly
Option C: Any attached cameras or sensors are operating normally.
Explanation: While it is advisable to ensure that the cameras or sensors are operating normally before flight, they will not affect the safety of the UAS operation and therefore are not required to be part of a preflight inspection.

Question: When can a small unmanned aircraft (sUAS) fly over 10,000 MSL?
Option A: When flying 400' AGL or below (or if higher than 400' AGL, must remain 400' of a structure)
Explanation: According to Part 107 regulations, Maximum flight altitude of 400 feet above ground level (AGL) or, if higher than 400 feet AGL, remain within 400 feet of a structure.

Question: In the event of an in-flight emergency, what action is the RPIC permitted to take?
Option A: Deviate from any Part 107 regulation to respond to the emergency
Option B: Activate the UAS's return-to-home automation failsafe mode only
Option C: Conduct any action to meet the emergency without regard to minmial injury or damage.
Explanation: 14 CFR 91.3 states that ìIn an in-flight emergency requiring immediate action, the RPIC may deviate from any rule of this part to the extent required to meet that emergency.î The RPIC should only deviate from these rules in order to minimize damage and injury in the emergency situation, so C is not correct. A ìreturn to home automation mode onlyî is mainly used by RPICs if they need to take control from the person manipulating the sUAS and does not need to be used in an emergency because it is permitted at all times.

Question: You are a qualified RPIC and want to share the controls with a friend who is also a qualified RPIC. Under what conditions are you allowed to transfer control?
Option A: When one of you can maintain Visual line of sight at all times without loss of control
Option B: When both of you can maintain VLOS while simultaneously acting as RPIC
Option C: When both of you can maintain VLOS at all times without loss of control
Explanation: sUASís can switch hands of qualified RPICís during a flight only if all pilots can maintain a VLOS with the sUAS, they are all aware of the safety factors involved with the flight, and there is no loss of control at any time. It is also recommended that a ìpositive change of controlsî takes place, in which there is a verbal communication where the pilots explicitly state who is in control at what time so the handoff is clear and established among all parties.

Question: Under what cicumstances would an accident report need to be made to the FAA?
Option A: sUAS causes $600 of damage to a fence that has a fair market price of $200
Option B: sUAS cause $600 of damage to a fence that has a fair market price of $700
Explanation: 14 CFR Part 107.9 states that if the fair market price is below $500 there is no need to report the accident to the FAA, as well as if the only property damaged is the sUAS, therefore the only scenario in which the accident would need to be reported is B since the fair market price of the fence is $700 > $500.
